230 Special Limits

8. Iterated Ends and Limits

We now describe when the “double integral” can be obtained as an “iterated” integral (Fubini!).

**Proposition.** Let \( S : P^{\text{op}} \times P \times C^{\text{op}} \times C \to X \) be a functor such that the end \( \int_{c} S(p, q, c, c) \) exists for all pairs \( \langle p, q \rangle \) of objects of \( P \); by the parameter theorems, regard these ends as a bifunctor \( P^{\text{op}} \times P \to X \), and regard \( S \) as a bifunctor \( (P \times C)^{\text{op}} \times (P \times C) \to X \). Then there is an isomorphism
\[ \theta : \int_{\langle p, c \rangle} S(p, c, p, c) \cong \int_{c} \left[ \int_{c} S(p, p, c, c) \right]. \]

Indeed, the “double end” on the left exists if and only if the end \( \int_{c} \) on the right exists, and then there is a unique arrow \( \theta \) in \( X \) such that the diagram
\[\begin{array}{ccc}
\int_{\langle p, c \rangle} S(p, p, c, c) & \xrightarrow{\xi_{(p, c)}} & S(p, p, c, c) \\
\theta & \downarrow & \downarrow \\
\int_{c} \left[ \int_{c} S(p, p, c, c)\right] & \xrightarrow{\theta_{p}} & \int_{c} S(p, p, c, c) \xrightarrow{\omega_{p, p, c}} S(p, p, c, c)
\end{array}\]
commutes, where the horizontal arrows \( \xi, \theta, \) and \( \omega \) are the universal wedges belonging to the corresponding ends; moreover, the arrow \( \theta \) is an isomorphism.

**Proof.** For each \( \langle p, q \rangle \in P \times P \) we are given the end
\[ \omega_{p, q} : \int_{c} S(p, q, c, c) \xrightarrow{\omega} S(p, q, -, -). \]

For any \( x \in X \) each \( P \)-indexed family \( \rho_{p} : x \to \int_{c} S(p, p, c, c) \) of arrows of \( X \) determines a \( (P \times C) \)-indexed family \( \xi_{p, c} \) as the composites
\[ \xi_{p, c} : x \xrightarrow{\theta_{p}} \int_{c} S(p, p, c, c) \xrightarrow{\omega} S(p, p, c, c); \]
for \( p \) fixed, \( \xi_{\langle p, - \rangle} \) is trivially a wedge in \( c \). Conversely, since \( \omega_{p, p} \) is universal, every \( (P \times C) \)-indexed family which is natural in \( c \) for each \( p \) is such a composite, for a unique family \( \theta \). Now \( \theta \) or \( \xi \) is extranatural in \( p \) (the latter for some \( c \)) if and only if the corresponding square below
\[\begin{array}{ccc}
x \xrightarrow{\theta_{p}} \int_{c} S(p, p, c) & \xrightarrow{\xi_{p, c}} & S(p, p, c, c) \\
\theta_{q} & \downarrow & \downarrow \\
\int_{c} S(p, s, c, c) & \xrightarrow{\xi_{q, c}} & S(p, s, c, c) \\
\int_{c} S(q, q, c, c) & \xrightarrow{\xi_{c}} & S(p, q, c, c)
\end{array}\]
